dc:description: The FOXI1 gene has been associated with autosomal recessive enlarged vestibular aqueduct syndrome using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of 5/19/17. Association is seen in one proband with a de novo heterozygous missense variant (Liu et al. 2016 27997596). Association was also made in at least 5 probands with missense variants by Yang et al. 2007 (17503324). These associations were subsequently disputed by Choi et al. 2009 (DOI 10.1002/humu.21098). This gene-disease association is supported by expression studies and protein interaction studies. Of note, this gene has also been implicated in hearing loss and renal tubular acidosis​. This been​ assessed separately. In summary, there is convincing evidence disputing the association between FOXI1 and autosomal recessive enlarged vestibular aqueduct syndrome. More evidence is needed to either support or refute the role FOXI1 plays in this disease. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hearing Loss Working Group on 2/27/18.
curationReasonDescription: Cases reported by Yang et al 2007 were subsequently disputed. A case reported by Lui et al. 2016 present a proband who only carries a variant on one allele. Additional reported cases provided no evidence for variant pathogenicity.

evidence.dc:description: Only one variant (heterozyous) identified in the proband. Paternity was not confirmed.
evidence for digenic inheritance, would explain heterozygous patients
Slc26A4, Foxi1 double heterozygous mice have EVA
evidence.rdfs:label: Yang Animal Model

evidence.dc:description: Knockout was embryonic lethal, so hearing could not be assessed, and developmental abnormalities were much more extensive than EVA

Homozygous null zebrafish embryos had morphologically defective ear development. Otic placode size was reduced and was split into two or more tiny placodes. Expression in WT fish was restricted to the area which would become the otic placode
evidence.rdfs:label: Nissen Animal Model

evidence.dc:description: supports EVA phenotype/similarity to Pendred syndrome in humans

In homozygous null mice, expression of SLC26A4 was absent from the endolymphatic epithelium, however it was normal in the cochlea. COCH expression was also missing in the endolymphatic duct/sac epithelium but present in other inner ear structures.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hulander Protein interaction

evidence.dc:description: Expression of foxi1 was characterized in medaka, aka the Japanese rice fish. In situ hybridization showed Foxi1 expression in the otic precursor cells very early in development, but not later. Foxi1 was then detectable again after 34 somite stage.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hochmann Expression

evidence.dc:description: Fkh10 was expressed in the mouse inner ear. Distinct expression in the otic vesicle in 9.5-day old embryos
evidence.rdfs:label: Hulander Expression
